snippet: Campaigns have had limited success trying to control how television networks show their candidates during debates, especially in split-screen and reaction shots.
abstract: Political campaigns have tried with limited success to control how television networks portray their candidates during debates, especially split-screen and reaction shots that can reinforce negative viewer attitudes about candidates they oppose; such shots likely contributed to perception that Pres Obama was disengaged during his debate against Mitt Romney.
lead_paragraph: Campaigns have had limited success trying to control how television networks show their candidates during debates, especially in split-screen and reaction shots.

headline.seo: Networks Like Split-Screens in Debates, Even if Candidates Don’t
headline.main: Networks Like Split-Screens in Debates, Even if the Candidates Don’t
